content.description: Start low on the north side of the sloping east face in a shallow dish by a small tree. Follow the slopey arête, traversing south until meeting with Hay Ride, and then top out.
content.location: On the northeast corner of the boulder, look for a shallow dish next to a tree. Match your hands, throw a heel, and follow the arete.

content.description: Start standing at low point of slopey southwestern arête. Your left hand is on a huge sloper, and your right hand is on a positive, pinchy feature. Move up and right along arête to a bulge, and then top out as for Pain in the Pullman.The problem itself is an easier alternate start for PITP. The two lines meet after a couple moves and then finish the same.
content.location: Find the juggy ledge for PITP, and look up to the arete.

content.description: Start on the southwest side of the boulder below the overhang. Establish yourself in a tough low sit start along obvious, juggy ledge. Make tough moves up onto the arête, then follow up and right to a slopey bulge. Top out on relatively good holds.
content.location: It climbs the Southwest overhung face of the boulder on the juggy ledge.

content.description: Start on the east face on the obvious crimp rail. Move straight up using underclings and slopers to top out. Hay Ride is a good warm-up climb with some nice holds and technicality.
content.location: On the East face. look for a good crimp rail on a mostly blank face.

content.description: Stud Finder is a lone, 12 foot, glacial erratic boulder sitting on a small hill. From the north side, it is a very gradually sloping, smooth rock, but the southwest, south, and southeast faces have high quality routes, marked typically by bad feet, slopers, and occasional small crimps.
